channel.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
channel.description:
Hey guys, for the past year and a half, I have been self-teaching myself Java Programming. I have read a couple books on it, and I'm not quite familiar with the language.
Private servers aren't my thing, to say the least. I want to get into Game development and very visual software. Java swing just isn't enough for me, I've made simple games with Java swing, and I want to take it up a notch.
So I ask you guys, do you know of websites, books, of any sort. That jump in Java Game Development? Obviously I have used Google and found a few, but I want to get your opinions on what you have found and what you find to be good/bad.

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @Racist_Turtle Racist Turtle
item.description:
@Racist_Turtle wrote:

Erj:

I see what you mean, but you did ask for something to start on. So I gave you what I found.

And I appreciate it.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Racist_Turtle wrote:

I appreciate the offer with those videos, but no. I dislike bucky’s videos a lot. Sure he may be good at teaching them, but hardly goes into any detail at all from where I want to go. Sure it’s a place to start, but there are plenty of other places to start as well.

Read full topic

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @bballin24 bballin24
item.description:
@bballin24 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:18, topic:410432”]I actually glossed over the 2d section. I only ever focused on the 3d stuff. I’ll look over it again and get back to you.

Yeah, I have no troubles helping you understand it, or help you get beyond the limitations of the book. It took me a very long time to understand all the mathematical principles behind 3d rendering, but you’ll see they prove to be pretty simple if they are properly explained.[/quote]

Thanks, i’m finding the intimidation factor of 3d rendering to be a big factor in why i’m spending alot of time in the 2d section making sure I understand all the concepts

And thanks for your support!

Read full topic

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“bballin24, post:17, topic:410432”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=511717.msg3723032#msg3723032 date=1314070312]

There actually is a resoruce right now that I am using, but it is decently technical and it requires a good working knowledge of Java pretty much everything from console work to gui’s. Make sure you know all your basics and all the more complicated aspects of Java, having knowledge of extra stuff such as binary trees is recommended

Like everyone above me said a solid math background is needed for the 3d parts as trigonometry is highly needed for modelling and implementation

That being said if you have any questions about the book feel free to ask me i’m glad to help

http://www.brackeen.com/javagamebook/

It covers alot from threads - 2d graphics, animation etc - 3d models etc

Ah yes, I’m very familiar with DGIJ. I’ve reworked with several copies of his software engine, eventually building my own with some elements very closely based on his book. Nevertheless, I would not recommend it because it teaches people how to build a software 3d engine, and does a terrible job at doing so. His engine is rather slow and there is little practical use nowadays for a software engine.

It’s great for learning purposes, but not really for game development. I’m definitely planning on posting my own software engine in the future on these boards, but as a mere learning exercise. If someone wants to make a serious 3d game in Java, I would recommend using JOGL or LWJGL for starters, and maybe even a 3d engine like Xith3D or JMonkeyEngine.
[/quote]

But it is good for learning the aspects of game development going through what a game comprises of and what you need to know maybe not in the detail or complexity that others may desire. I havn’t reached the 3d section yet but I am going to be happy to get through it, what are your thoughts on the 2d section because even though it is small I am thoroughly enjoying it. so far. Also if I do end up having a few questions about 3d modelling would you mind answering at all? [/quote]

I actually glossed over the 2d section. I only ever focused on the 3d stuff. I’ll look over it again and get back to you.

Yeah, I have no troubles helping you understand it, or help you get beyond the limitations of the book. It took me a very long time to understand all the mathematical principles behind 3d rendering, but you’ll see they prove to be pretty simple if they are properly explained.

Edit: Yeah, I skimmed through the 2d sections again. They are pretty good for giving you a crash course into making a simple game using the Java2D architecture. I wouldn’t particularly recommend using Java2D, but many would argue there’s absolutely nothing wrong with it. It keeps your application entirely portable, and its speed is inconsiderable in a simple 2D game.

I do give it props for teaching the use of NIO for networking and multiplayer solutions, though.

Read full topic

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @bballin24 bballin24
item.description:
@bballin24 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:16, topic:410432”][quote author=bballin24 link=topic=511717.msg3722970#msg3722970 date=1314067998]
There actually is a resoruce right now that I am using, but it is decently technical and it requires a good working knowledge of Java pretty much everything from console work to gui’s. Make sure you know all your basics and all the more complicated aspects of Java, having knowledge of extra stuff such as binary trees is recommended

Like everyone above me said a solid math background is needed for the 3d parts as trigonometry is highly needed for modelling and implementation

That being said if you have any questions about the book feel free to ask me i’m glad to help

http://www.brackeen.com/javagamebook/

It covers alot from threads - 2d graphics, animation etc - 3d models etc

[/quote]

Ah yes, I’m very familiar with DGIJ. I’ve reworked with several copies of his software engine, eventually building my own with some elements very closely based on his book. Nevertheless, I would not recommend it because it teaches people how to build a software 3d engine, and does a terrible job at doing so. His engine is rather slow and there is little practical use nowadays for a software engine.

It’s great for learning purposes, but not really for game development. I’m definitely planning on posting my own software engine in the future on these boards, but as a mere learning exercise. If someone wants to make a serious 3d game in Java, I would recommend using JOGL or LWJGL for starters, and maybe even a 3d engine like Xith3D or JMonkeyEngine.[/quote]

But it is good for learning the aspects of game development going through what a game comprises of and what you need to know maybe not in the detail or complexity that others may desire. I havn’t reached the 3d section yet but I am going to be happy to get through it, what are your thoughts on the 2d section because even though it is small I am thoroughly enjoying it. so far. Also if I do end up having a few questions about 3d modelling would you mind answering at all?

Read full topic

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“bballin24, post:15, topic:410432”]There actually is a resoruce right now that I am using, but it is decently technical and it requires a good working knowledge of Java pretty much everything from console work to gui’s. Make sure you know all your basics and all the more complicated aspects of Java, having knowledge of extra stuff such as binary trees is recommended

Like everyone above me said a solid math background is needed for the 3d parts as trigonometry is highly needed for modelling and implementation

That being said if you have any questions about the book feel free to ask me i’m glad to help

http://www.brackeen.com/javagamebook/

It covers alot from threads - 2d graphics, animation etc - 3d models etc[/quote]

Ah yes, I’m very familiar with DGIJ. I’ve reworked with several copies of his software engine, eventually building my own with some elements very closely based on his book. Nevertheless, I would not recommend it because it teaches people how to build a software 3d engine, and does a terrible job at doing so. His engine is rather slow and there is little practical use nowadays for a software engine.

It’s great for learning purposes, but not really for game development. I’m definitely planning on posting my own software engine in the future on these boards, but as a mere learning exercise. If someone wants to make a serious 3d game in Java, I would recommend using JOGL or LWJGL for starters, and maybe even a 3d engine like Xith3D or JMonkeyEngine.

Read full topic

Like everyone above me said a solid math background is needed for the 3d parts as trigonometry is highly needed for modelling and implementation

That being said if you have any questions about the book feel free to ask me i’m glad to help

http://www.brackeen.com/javagamebook/

@Racist_Turtle wrote:

Speljohan:

Games development isn’t language-specific, use gamedev.net, they have quite a few informative articles.

I never said that the Game development was a language in of it self. I’m looking into Java Game Development. Thanks for the reference though.

Read full topic

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @Racist_Turtle Racist Turtle
item.description:
@Racist_Turtle wrote:

[quote="_s, post:11, topic:410432"][quote author=Racist Turtle link=topic=511717.msg3713921#msg3713921 date=1313519918]

Make sure you do know the basics and a lot of advanced concepts though like good design patterns and such, or you may develop a working game that performs poorly.

Start small, learn as you go. My first suggestion is just simple 2D games to learn more about Java graphics

Thanks, believe me, I’m very strict on “good, efficient, and readable/organized programming”. Thanks though, I probably need to look up more on advanced concepts.
[/quote]
try and remember that game development isn’t just something you can fly straight in to, a good game developer usually knows a fair amount of maths as well as programming related things. i’d recommend you start off learning/reminding yourself of things like trigonometry as it’s basically essential to figuring out things like collision and distancing etc. teach yourself to use a good library for graphics and learn about software design and data structures (basic ones as well as sorting and (graph?) searching algorithms) it helps to learn about graphics too, ie. what an alpha level is, rotation algorithms, etc.

when you’re ready to move into 3D you’ll want to learn good amounts of linear algebra, calculus and even more comp-sci/programming things but with the latter it’s more a case of “you’ll learn it when you need it” rather than a bunch of prerequisites however knowing how matrices work and such is going to be a definite prerequisite in the 3D world.[/quote]

Thanks, what you just said was very helpful. I somewhat forgot about the Math part of game development, and not everything will be just a prerequisite inside a book. Thanks man.

Read full topic

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Racist Turtle, post:10, topic:410432”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=511717.msg3713652#msg3713652 date=1313504107]
Make sure you do know the basics and a lot of advanced concepts though like good design patterns and such, or you may develop a working game that performs poorly.

Start small, learn as you go. My first suggestion is just simple 2D games to learn more about Java graphics
[/quote]

Thanks, believe me, I’m very strict on “good, efficient, and readable/organized programming”. Thanks though, I probably need to look up more on advanced concepts.[/quote]
try and remember that game development isn’t just something you can fly straight in to, a good game developer usually knows a fair amount of maths as well as programming related things. i’d recommend you start off learning/reminding yourself of things like trigonometry as it’s basically essential to figuring out things like collision and distancing etc. teach yourself to use a good library for graphics and learn about software design and data structures (basic ones as well as sorting and (graph?) searching algorithms) it helps to learn about graphics too, ie. what an alpha level is, rotation algorithms, etc.

when you’re ready to move into 3D you’ll want to learn good amounts of linear algebra, calculus and even more comp-sci/programming things but with the latter it’s more a case of “you’ll learn it when you need it” rather than a bunch of prerequisites however knowing how matrices work and such is going to be a definite prerequisite in the 3D world.

Read full topic

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

CoonHunter:

There is no specifics on developing a game in Java. The best bet is to find some open-souce games made in Java that you can learn from. Find some graphics library implementations (jlwgl is what Minecraft uses) and work with those.

lwjgl*

Read full topic

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Make sure you do know the basics and a lot of advanced concepts though like good design patterns and such, or you may develop a working game that performs poorly.

Start small, learn as you go. My first suggestion is just simple 2D games to learn more about Java graphics

Developing Games in Java by David Brackeen is the best book I have read on the topic. It is indeed very good, so it’s def. worth buying. You can read about it here http://www.brackeen.com/javagamebook/.

item.title: (Game Development != Runescape) Where to Start?
item.dc:creator: @Racist_Turtle Racist Turtle
item.description:
@Racist_Turtle wrote:

Hey guys, for the past year and a half, I have been self-teaching myself Java Programming. I have read a couple books on it, and I’m not quite familiar with the language.

Private servers aren’t my thing, to say the least. I want to get into Game development and very visual software. Java swing just isn’t enough for me, I’ve made simple games with Java swing, and I want to take it up a notch.

So I ask you guys, do you know of websites, books, of any sort. That jump in Java Game Development? Obviously I have used Google and found a few, but I want to get your opinions on what you have found and what you find to be good/bad.

Read full topic
